author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Large optic nerves suspicious for  glaucoma
content: Hi, You have not mentioned her disc size. However, i have provided some information that may help you to comprehend the reasons why interpretation of this measurement is so complex.  Vertical elongation of the optic cup is a characteristic feature of glaucomatous optic neuropathy. Interpretation of optic cup sizes and determining their relevance to glaucoma is highly complex and not fully understood.  The optic disc and optic cup dimentions vary widely in the normal population. The vertical cup to disc ratio (VCDR) is a simple, and fairly dependable indicator of glaucomatous loss of the neuroretinal rim. Unlike other measures of optic nerve morphology, such as rim area, clinical estimations of the VCDR are commonly performed by most ophthalmologists and do not require multiple measurements or additional imaging equipment. However, a large variation within normal populations, as well as significant overlap in VCDR between normal and glaucomatous eyes has been observed, thereby limiting its usefulness.  The 97.5th percentile for vertical cup to disc ratio (VCDR) has been proposed as a useful tool to assist in the diagnosis of glaucoma in population studies.  The size of an optic disk image depends on factors such as, - the magnification properties of the eye (axial length, ametropia and   corneal curvature),  - instrument magnification, - the measurement technique, - race, - gender etc.  There are many techniques available for measurement of optic disc size. Some of which are,  - Slit-lamp biomicroscopy,  - Planimetry, and  - Confocal scanning laser ophthalmoscopy (CSLO)  Direct measurement of the optic disc size can be done only during vitreoretinal surgery or histologically.  African-Americans have been noted to have larger disks than individuals from other races. However, based on the measured values using a variety of methods, estimates of the mean disk size in African-Americans range from 2.14 mm 2 to 3.75 mm compared with 1.73 mm to 2.63 mm in Caucasians, and 2.46 mm to 2.67 mm in Hispanics, and 2.47 mm to 3.22 mm in Asians.  The high prevalence of glaucoma in individuals of certain African and African-Carribean populations (2.8% to 8.8%) combined with the presence of larger optic disks compared to the Caucasian population has led to the hypothesis that large optic disks might be more prone to glaucomatous damage than small disks. It is possible, that various other factors may be involved in the higher rates of glaucoma seen in African-Americans. These may include genetic susceptibility to Primary open-angle glaucoma, higher prevalence of comorb conditions, such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes and systemic hypertension, or thin corneas.  Disk size between genders varies slightly(males>females), but not to the extent of being statistically significant. No studies have directly evaluated whether sex and disk size influences the susceptibility of glaucoma. Age does not appear to be associated with disk size. No evidence for a relationship between age, disk size and susceptibility to glaucoma has been reported yet in humans. Myopia (worse than 5 diopters) has been seen to increase the odds of having glaucoma while hyperopia has an opposite effect.  I hope this information is of help. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Sudden blurred vision in left eye, lasting a few seconds
content: Hi, At the outset, i must stress that a consulation with an ophthalmologist is the right thing for you to do.  However, i will discuss a condition which can cause the symptoms such as yours, which is not often in the limelight- the entity known as  "Subnormal accommodation".  Weakening of accommodation does exist and is known to cause persistent & annoying symptoms long before the presbyopic age.  It is so easily overlooked because, - its relative infrequency, - near-point of accommodation and its range are not routinely tested as part of refration testing.  Subnormal power of accommodation is a not an infrequent cause of asthenopia in young persons and may be seen more often in members of the same family. It remains a distinct condition only in the young individuals & after middle age it is difficult to distinguish from presbyopia. Headaches and defective near vision are the chief complaints.  Other symptoms which may occur are.. - conjunctival irritation, - blurred near vision,and   - difficulty in performing close work.    Diagnosis: The only way perhaps is to test the range of the accommodation - sadly, often a much neglected procedure.  Trust this information may be of use to you.I am unable however, to explain the transient nature of your experience. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Eye's Blacking and hurts to blink
content: Hi, Your description strongly resembles the signs and symptoms of Giant cell arteritis (GCA)- (variously known as cranial arteritis, temporal arteritis and granulomatous arteritis).  Etiology: Not known.Following factors may be involved: - genetic,   - environmental, - infective?  Epidemiology:  2-3 times more common in Women.Typically seen in female patients >50 years of age.   Vessels involved: Although it usually presents with involvement of the superficial temporal arteries, this inflammatory process has been found to involve medium and large-sized vessels, (arch of aorta and its branches).Cranial and visual symptoms are due to involvement of the ophthalmic, posterior ciliary, and to a lesser extent,the central artery of the retina .   Pathogenesis:  endothelial injury --- activation of cell-mediated immunity --- release of cytokines ---- damage to internal elastic lamina, intimal hyperplasia, transmural inflammation, & eventual stenotic occlusion.  Presenting symptoms:  - Constitutional symptoms (fever, anorexia, weight loss, malaise, impaired memory and depression). - cranial symptoms: new-onset headache(usually temporal), severe scalp tenderness, facial pain, earache, jaw claudication,  toothache, pain in the tongue, palatal pain and odynophagia. - visual symptoms: blurred vision, diplopia, and loss of vision.  - polymyalgia rheumatica symptoms may be associated (approximately 50% of cases).  Signs: tenderness over the course of the temporal artery is the most typical sign( but, not always present).  Labs:  - high erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), - elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) (even in patients with a normal ESR),  - Complete blood cell count (CBC) may reveal anemia, leukocytosis or thrombocytosis.  Complications:  The most devastating complication of temporal arteritis is irreversible vision loss, which can be - unilateral,or - Bilateral.  Diagnosis: Temporal artery biopsy in all cases of suspected GCA must be done.In a  few patients biopsies may be negative(explained by  “skip” lesions).If biopsy is negative,the other side must be biosied. Ultrasonography, CT scans,angiographic examination,and high resolution MRI and position emission tomography (PET). may be indicated in some cases.  Treatment: Mainstay is Glucocorticoid therapy.Daily doses preferred.Relapses may occur.Relapses may necessitate increased dosage or prolonged steroid treatment. Addition of methotrexate is controversial. So,the routine addition of methotrexate to glucocorticoid therapy is not recommended.   Other drugs such as dapsone, aspirin, antimalarials, other cytotoxic drugs, penicillamine, and etanercept are being investigated.  You should consult your family doctor so that he/she may be able to decide on the course of action in your case. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: loss of vision due to optical nerve in right eye
content: Hi, From the history provided, some possibilities need to be considered. - Congenital eye disorders(congenital optic atrophy,congenital cataract,and congenital glaucoma), - an 'Early onset' macular degeneration &  - Retinitis pigmentosa etc.  What ever the cause, management of these children with with low vision continues to be challenging.    There is no consensus as yet on the ideal management for these children. Some studies have reported that children with severely impaired contrast sensitivity function showed lower reading speeds compared to those with the same near visual acuity, but better contrast sensitivity function.Even a small reductions in contrast were noted to reduce reading performance in almost all low vision patients tested, hence they need higher magnification for reading.Other studies have disputed this.  Several studies have shown that low vision aids were very effective in helping 90% of the low vision patients to read normal size prints. Also distance telescopes were found to be effective in improving visual performance both indoors and outdoors. As far as the compliance is concerned, some studies indicate that about 90% of children remained users of their telescopes(both far vision and near vision aids) at 1 year and abot 50% at 2 years with improvement of visual function.  In conclusion, one may (based on available evidence) derive that low vision, which has a wide-ranging impact on the behavior of children and adolescents can be helped considerably by vision rehabilitation with the use of optical vision aids,which have been found to be very helpful in minimizing the impact of low vision and in improving their overall performance.  Based on the available evidence, i feel that your child will be certainly benefited by the low vision aids & should be given a chance to use them under supervision of an ophthalmologist. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Dry eyes, sensitive to light, change in iris color
content: Hi, Thank you for your post and the attached image. Most eye-color changes have been reported in the Caucasian populations with hazel eyes.  Heterochromia iridis/iridum is a color change that occurs in the iris. This can be of two types based on whether there is loss or addition of pigment as: - hypochromic & - hyperchromic.  They may also be classified based on the extent of surface area involved as: - complete heterochromia, wherein one iris is of a completely different color from the other & - sectoral heterochromia(partial), wherein part(a sector) of one iris is a different color from rest of the areas. Complete heterochromia is much more common.Sectoral heterochromia  is mostly associated with autosomally inherited disorders like Waardenburg syndrome and Hirschsprung's disease.Sectoral type can also occur post-trauma.  The color change in the iris can be of many types which include - central (close to the pupillary margin), - peripheral - nodular - trabecular network (such as in leukemias)  - stellate etc.  Glaucoma can cause iris transillumination defects, trabecular patterns as well as concentric rings in the iris.  Latanoprost-induced pigmentation: Lantoprost is an antiglaucoma medication      (a prostaglandin F2 alpha analogue), which can cause increased growth of eyelashes (hypertrichosis) & iris pigmentation.  One particular study in patients with brown eyes had shown occurrence of concentric hyperpimentation. ( Wistrand PJ, Stjernschantz J & Olsson K. The incidence and time-course of latanoprost-induced iridial pigmentation as a function of eye color. Surv Ophthalmol 1997; 41: 129138.).  You may refer to the following link as well. ( http://www.doctorslounge.com/forums/vie ... 90&t=43584 ).  Solar damage also is known to cause pigment changes in the iris.Also, anterior segment dispersion syndrome is known to cause concentric transillumination defects in mostly teenagers.  The diagnosis in your case may be arrived at only after consultation with an ophthalmologist. Best wishes!!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Ciprofloxacion Ophthalmic Solution for a stye
content: Hi, Styes (hordeola) are infective conditions of the eyelids usually by the organism Staphylococcus aureus.   They are of two basic types: - Hordeolum Externum: which is a suppurative inflammation of one of the glands of Zeis or Moll, located anterior to the lash line(more superficial) & - Hordeolum Internum: which is an inflammation of one of the meibomian glands(or tarsal glands)of the eyelid (situated deeper).  One other condition affecting the eyelids is a chalazion. This will not be discussed further here.  Predisposing factors for hordeola: - seborrheic blepharitis, - Uncorrected Refractive errors,  - Poor lid hygiene, - Low resistance to staphylococci & - Diabetes Mellitus.  Hordeola are usually self-limiting, and generally spontaneously resolve within a couple of weeks.  Medical therapy for hordeola includes  - eyelid hygiene,  - warm compresses  - massaging of the lesions for 10 minutes 4 times a day, and  - topical antibiotic ointments,if the lesion is already draining, or if there is associated conjunctivitis.  Systemic antibiotics may be indicated if complicated by preseptal cellulitis.  A number of topical antibiotics have been used in the management of hordeola notably, - chloramphenicol, - tobramicin & - Quinolones (Ciprofloxacin, ofoloxacin).  One may use ointments or drops, but ointments are preferred by some(especially when associated with blepharitis).  Ciprofloxacin has shown comparable efficiency compared to chloramphenicol and tobramycin in the treatment of conjunctivitis and blepharitis. Safety profile also appears to be similar.   Some workers had observed the appearance of a white precipitate as the only potentially adverse effect in the cases treated with ciprofloxacin. The precipitate resolved sponteneously in all patients and did not appear to cause any scarring of the cornea.This precipitation has been explained by an alteration in the pH of the eye-drops as they mix with the tears. ( http://www.pharmj.com/editorial/2000031 ... tics2.html )  Thus one may conclude that topical antibiotics are not indicated in all cases of hordeola and the decision as to when to use them be preferably left to the ophthalmologists. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Changing Iris color
content: Hi, Subtle changes in the color  of the irides occur throughout life and with disease. In some individuals, changes in iris color from 6 years of age to adulthood is seen.  Iridiseumelanin (a type of melanin) which is synthesized by melanocytes,is responsible for the color of the irides. Different colors exist in the population due to  - the density of melanocytes and - the variations among the eumelanin.  Color of a given iris is usually not uniform, as different parts of the iris contain eumelanin variations. These differences in color are not very perceptible in uniformly colored eyes like gray eyes, but is more noticeable in people with hazel eyes, as they have more variations in color.  There are a host of conditions where changes in color occur, which, to a lay person's untrained eyes, may simply look like a color change, but to an ophthalmologist it may mean - a change in color, - a defect in the iris, - 'transillumination' or transparency, - iris nodules, - freckles, - iris nevi, - iris cysts, - iris tumors etc.  Iris color change may be unilateral or bilateral.  There are certain instances in which permanent change to the iris color does occur. This may be due to injury, the increased production of melanin following birth, exposure to the sun, certain eye treatments for glaucoma, etc.  As the list of causes of changes in iris color are too many to discuss in detail, i will try to present some of the more common or interesting ones:  - Heterochromia is a color change that occurs in the iris. This can be of two types:- complete heterochromia, where one iris is of a completely different color from the other & - sectoral heterochromia(partial), wherein part (a sector) of one iris is a different color from rest of the areas. Complete heterochromia is more common.Sectoral heterochromia  is mostly associated with found in autosomally inherited disorders such as Waardenburg syndrome and Hirschsprung's disease.  - Anterior segment dispersion syndrome:causes transillumination defects in mostly teenagers. - Lisch nodules: these hamartomas consisting of melanocytic cells containing varying amounts of pigment. These are pathognomonic of type 1 neurofibromatosis (NF1).They are likely to be seen in 90-100% of NF1 patients over 6 years of age. - inflammatory uveitis of sarcoidosis. - iris freckles and nevi: - congenital: congenital sectoral melanocytic hypoplasia, in which involvement is seen as a brown sector on green iris or a brown sector an a blue iris.May be associated with neural crest anomalies, Ex; Hirshprung's congenital deafness and poliosis. - Darkening of the iris colour is an increasingly reported side effect of  prostaglandin analogues, such as latanoprost and isopropyl unoprostone1. - trauma induced color changes(including surgical trauma). - tumors (both benign and malignant) of the iris: of the benign tumors, melanocytoma needs mention. Mosttly occurs in African-Americans, & have a very low risk for malignant transformation. Among malignant tumors, primary ocular melanoma is the commonest. Best wishes!

title: Long-lasting blurred streaks
content: I am 15 years old and within the last half year I have experienced, maybe 5-6 times, fairly long-lasting (30mins-1 hour) fuzzy,gray/clear streaks appearing in mainly my right eye on entering a bright room. Unlike the normal spots or streaks that you get in your eye after a camera flash, these seem to move about in an odd fashion, almost like the flowing of water and they do not go away after a short period of time. They also do not occur after sudden bright flashes of light, such as from a camera, but more after entering a brightly lit building or room. These streaks, as mentioned above, appear mainly in my right eye, making it difficult to focus on things, therefore difficult to read. However, closing the right eye does not help, as these streaks then seem to appear in the top right corner of my left eye, as if flowing from one eye to the other.  Closing my eyes has never helped solve this problem, as the streaks are there when my eyes are closed, shining more of a yellow color. What once helped was putting on a pair of sunglasses, or focusing in on an area that was not flooded in the lights of the room.  I have never experienced any pain while having this problem, however once it did leave behind a minor headache once I had successfully gotten rid of it.  The first time I had this problem, was walking into a supermarket in Spain. I was already inside a normal shopping mall, but somehow the main building of the mall was not lit in the same way as the supermarket and my eyes did not react well to this change.   What could this problem be and what could it be caused by?

title: Re: Swollen eye lids, dry scaly tissue, & tightness around eyes
content: Hello,The eyelids are very prone to allergic contact dermatitis due to the thin skin which allows the allergen to pass through.Many a times the allergen comes from the fingers, like nail polish.Nickel sensitization is common.ABCD ie AirBorneContactDermatitis is plant pollens causing the allergy.I would recommend you to get a patch testing to identify the allergen.Steroid cremes on the eyelid are used with caution for fear of absorbtion.The least potency are prefered like hydrocorisone creme.The eye irritation is best controlled with oral antihistaminics.

content: Hi, first of all, get the cause of the dry eyes treated if there is any, instead of symptomatically treating the dry eyes. author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Twitchy Eye for 3 months
content: Hi, Twitching of the eye lid/lids alone is usually called as 'Myokymia'.This is due to what are called as 'fasiculations', which means involuntary contractions of a small group of otherwise normal muscle fibers.Seen usually in conditions of stress,fatigue,and excessive caffeine or alcohol consumption.   If these involuntary contractions of the orbicularis oculi muscle of the eyelids are associated with contractions of muscles in some part of the face, conditions such as 'Blepharospasm'. hemifacial spasm etc will need to be considered.  Blepharospasm is known to be associated with irritation in the eyes,tearing, vague ocular pain and photophobia.  It is possible that you might not have observed some other part of your face moving during the episodes.Blepharospasm needs to be excluded in your case.I suggest that you should first consult an ophthalmologist who will be able to guide you better after examining you. Best wishes!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Fri Nov 20, 2009 9:32 am

author: Dr. Ramamurthy M G  Medical Doctor Posts: 90 Joined: Sun Dec 28, 2008 9:47 pm Gender: Male

content: Hello, I am a 24 year old generally healthy female, and I have an eye problem that I would like some insight on.  For the past three days, I have been seeing a flash that very persistently will not go away. It is in my left eye, slightly above my direct line of vision. It is small and shadowy-blue, like a camera flash only not as intense, and it's not really obstructing my vision, but it's not going away. I've had slight headaches at night recently, but not serious. I've also had a slight pain under my eye in my cheekbone area that comes on for a few seconds and disappears.  I do not have a history of eye problems, although I do wear prescription glasses that are not very strong. I have been diagnosed with having "acute inflammatory arthritis", although I am confident that the type of arthritis I have is palindromic rheumatism. I am not on any medications.  I went to my optometrist today, and the doctor told me that what he could do is rule out problems with my retina. And he ended up telling me that my retina was fine, and told me to come back in 4 to 6 weeks if anything changes or gets worse. He said that the problem could be in the very early stages, and therefore undetectable as of yet.   Tomorrow will be my fourth day seeing this flash, and I am wondering if it would be a good idea to go to the hospital. I don't want to wait 4 to 6 weeks, as I have read multiple sources online that say this could be serious, whether it is retina related or not, the problem needs to be detected early. I have done quite a bit of searching, and have not found anyone else describing the same problem. Thank you for your help.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Persistent photopsia
content: Hi, ' Scotomas' occur in anumber of conditions.'Scotoma' that you describe,suggests a 'Scintillating scotoma' which is perhaps the most frequently associated 'aura' associated with Migraine.Migraine can occur without headaches,the so-called 'acephalgic migraine', which also can present with reccurring  'Scintillating scotomas.'   'Punctate inner choroiditis' (PIC) is another condition which should be excluded.  'Punctate inner choroiditis' presents with bilateral (inflammatory) choroidal lesions of the posterior pole of the eyes.Pathogenesis is uncertain. It occurs mostly in young, otherwise healthy, myopic women.Generally carries a good visual prognosis if diagnosed and treated promptly( oral and regional steroids).  Ofcourse,your doctor was right in first excluding more serious conditions such as posterior vitrious detachnment and retinal detachment etc. Best wishes!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Sat Nov 21, 2009 11:18 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: unequal dialated pupils
content: Hi, Unequal pupils are termed anisocoria are due to a variety of causes. Anisocoria may be physiological or pathological.   Yhey may also be classified as neurologic and others non-neurologic.  Physiologyic (non-neurologic) anisocoria: • occurs in about 20% of the population • response to light and near testing is normal • The difference size between the two pupils is less than 2mm • inequality of the pupils depend on either the amount of ambient light or the time of observation.  It is possible that your description may indicate a Physiologic (non-neurologic) anisocoria. Only an ophthalmologist after fully examining you would be in a position to come to a final conclusive diagnosis. Best wishes!
posted_time: Post  by Dr.M.Aroon kamath » Sat Nov 21, 2009 9:40 pm

title: Morning dry eyes, shadow vision, light sensitivity
content: I cannot figure out what's going on with my eyes. I've went to 4 ophthalmologist, and they all tell me that my eyes are healthy and don't need corrective lenses. They don't understand why my vision is so poor.  Here is some information on myself: - Female - 25 years old - 115 lbs. - No previous eye disorder, 20/20 vision - Good health - Lived in Bellingham WA when symptoms started - Currently live in Los Angeles.  When the symptoms started, I thought it was just a side effect from stress and anxiety. At that time, my house had a Hobo Spider infestation, I was being interviewed for graduate school and I was planning my move to California. The symptoms were (from what I remember): - Red Eyes lasted for 3 days (that i used OTC drops for) - Blurred/ shadowed vision that was severly worse at night - Dry eyes when I woke up (as if I left my eyes open all night) - My right eye had it worse than my left.  My symptoms now are: - Severly dry eyes in the morning - Terrible light sensitivity - Poor Vision: Can't read street signs unless I'm standing directly in front of it, shadowed vision, seems like I have a "dreamy/hazy" filter on my lens - Feel disoriented - Eyes feel very strained, tired and heavy after 2 hours of continuous use on one task. - Occasional sharp pain in the back of my eye - Headaches in the back of my head and temples.  If you have ANY idea that I can suggest to my ophthalmologist, please post. It's been 3 months since I can see clearly. It's been taxing on my life I feel like depressed sometimes. I really would like my life back.  I would also like to add that I used to wear plano contact lenses, and found myself leaving them in when I slept. However, if there were any damage, I'm sure the 4 ophthalmologist would have found something, right?

author: Dr. Ramamurthy M G  Medical Doctor Posts: 90 Joined: Sun Dec 28, 2008 9:47 pm Gender: Male
title: Re: Eye allergies
content: Hi, if it is an allergic conjunctivitis, there is no need for so many drops and ointments, other than anti allergics like patanol and may be artificial tears. Diagnosis need to be confirmed. It might be associated dry eyes also. The real cause needs to be treated rather than the symptoms. Avoid the things to which you are allergic to. Protect yor eyes with goggles when you go out. Have a gentle eye wash once you come back. Avoid peeling mucous from your eyes, since the secretion becomes more and more if you continue to peel. Drops are fine, but the cause?. Probably you sholud stop everything and continue with artificial tears  and may be only patanol for a while, incase if you have used medications beyond one month. Take care. Regards, Dr. Ramamurthy M G

title: Uveitis after LASIK. Steroid Responder
content: Hi,   I had LASIK on Aug 15. Doctor put me on TobraDex 2 Drops every 2 Hours for the firs day. Second Day he reduced the dosage to 4 drops a day but I mis understood & but 2 drops in each eye 4 times a day. After a week the doctor measured My eye pressure & noted it was a little high. He gave me Alphagan 2 drops a day to control the IOP and asked me to take the topradex 4 times a day for 1 week (one drop each time), then gradually reduce the dosage by one drop every week. By the end of the 4th week I started to have blurred vision & went to see the doctor.   My IOP was 40-Right Eye 42-Left Eye so he told me to stop the Tobradex immediately (I`m a steroid responder which we never knew before)) and gave me TIMOPTOL 2 Drops a day & increased the Alphagan to 3 drops a day.   After 3 days he measured my IOP & it was 10-12. He also noticed the I have developed Uveitis in both my eyes. He said I must take FLUCON 6 times a day to heal the Uveitis & keep taking the other medication to reduce my IOP.   IS this the right course of tratment? is there any other medications (Non-Steroid) to use instead of FUCON? Will my Uveitis take long to heal with this medicine? Will the high IOP for a few weeks cause Glaucoma? The doctor checked my retina & says its OK for now but will it get damaged while I use the steroid?  Thank you,

author: mplsquestion  Guest Posts: 5 Joined: Sat Aug 01, 2009 2:06 am Gender: Female
title: Re: Watering left eye when cold or windy
content: Hi!  I've had chronically watery eyes for about six years, and there is actually something you can do about it if it sincerely bothers you. The root of the problem could be a blocked tear duct (which is why it is only occuring in one eye, unlike allergies which would affect both). An opthalmologist could check this by inserting a small plastic syringe into the tear duct and trying to squeeze a little water down. Most likely it will be blocked and the water (like your excess tears) will run down your face instead of down the drain. It took me two years, but I have an excellent opthalmologist who performs a surgery to create a new tear duct, bypassing the old one if the syringe irrigation does not fix the problem long term. It's called a dachryocystorhinostomy, or a DCR surgery. It's an outpatient procedure that I have had, and the recovery time is just about a week. Do some research, maybe talk to your opthalmologist, but definitely look into it if it bothers you! I'm very, very glad that I did.  Feel free if you have any questions!

title: Optical Migraines
content: Hi, I am a healthy 35 year old female.  About a year ago, I started to occassionally get wavy vision in the corner of my right eye.  It happened every few months.  Within the past few months it has increased to almost weekly with wavy vision and lightening like bolts through the vision.  Only twice it appeared in my left eye with less severity, once it showed in the left as a blacked out area.  After researching it myself and going to my general prac. it was concluded that it was optical migraines but my doctor suggested I go to a opthamologist as well.  There was about a months time in between doctors appointments and in that time the right eye really started bothering me with fuzzy vision and floaters throughout the day (I did get hit in that eye during this time period) and I also have occassional dizziness.  The opthamologist also concluded that I am experiencing optical migraines and that the recent fuzzy vision with floaters might be the result of the hit in the eye loosening the gel in the eye.  The only thing the eye exam found was that my left eye is severely near sighted and the right eye is fine (both eyes used to be better than 20/20).  The doctor said he doesn't see a need for glasses since I am seeing fine and didn't even notice the nearsightedness.  My question is as follows: could the poor vision in my left eye be straining my right eye, causing all these problems; and, is there any reason for concern that I am having such frequent trouble with the right eye?   Is a second opinion necessary?

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Momentary vision loss in left eye when jarred
content: Hello --  While the other symptoms are more vague, the jarring seeming to cause unilateral vision loss for a moment each time strongly suggests a loose retina possibly at one corner. This can only lead to eventually detachment, so exam and, if needed, repair would be good sooner than later, with less indisposition and less risk of complications. See an opthamologist ASAP and meanwhile avoid jolts, jars, etc., as this could make a loosened retina worse. If everything turns out okay then other explanations will have to be sought, but the major symptom, along with those others, really does sound like an impending partial detachment.   Hope this is helpful. Good luck to you and please keep us updated.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Wed May 27, 2009 1:27 pm

title: Re: why do I see halo and sunburts in lights at night?
content: Hi, deposits on contact lenses, tear film in between and front and movement of the contact lenses with each blink can give rise to such issues. title: vision changes due to eye drops
content: Hi, I am a 45yr male who was recently diagnosed with suspected glaucoma. Suspected because a GDx scan revealed that my optic nerve was very thin. At that time my intra ocular pressure was 12 in both eyes. I had a normal "white light" vision field test and was sent to a specialist. A more sensitive field vision test came back abnormal and my pressures were 18 and 23 in left and right eyes. I was started on xalatan drops and a follow-up in 6wks. During my visit the Opthamologist dilated my eyes at approx 3:30PM. It took until the next morning for my eyes to be able to focus. At that time I noticed some near and far vision changes. The next day I started the xalatan. Five days after my visit I attended my childs school musical and couldn't see from my seat in the middle of the auditorium (usually I sit in the back). I went to my Optometrist 2 days later and he informed me that I had a significant change in vision since my vist there 4 months ago. New glasses are being made now. My question is, can drops to dilate your eyes (I assumed it was atropine; I didn't ask) cause permanent vision changes and has xalatan been known to cause permanent vision changes. Also, might my vision continue to worsen. By the way; I also have monocular vision due to amblyopia and am concerned about xalatan causing cataracts. Thanks in advance for any help you can give me.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Unequal eye vision
content: Hello --  "Normal" is extremely relative, and a vast number of us have abnormal eyesight, which is within healthy, normal range of abnormality (that is to say, we are not severely compromised).  Use of the word "normal" needs  to be weighed carefully by  doctors. While it is extremely common to be nearsighted in one eye,  and this is what appears to be the case with you, it is not "normal",  and if it causes symptoms, such as headache or eye fatigue, then it may well be helpful for you to have glasses prescribed, at least for reading. This can help a great deal in some cases, and almost  never does any harm.   I hope this helps. You should see an opthamologist and if  he doesn't suggest glasses,  you should ask for them. This isn't at all unreasonable  and will probably help relieve most of your  symptoms. Good luck to you with this. Please follow up with us here as needed.

author: Dr. Ramamurthy M G  Medical Doctor Posts: 90 Joined: Sun Dec 28, 2008 9:47 pm Gender: Male
title: Re: Unequal eye vision
content: Hi, it is not very abnormal to have unequal vision in our eyes. we come across cases, where in one eye might be just normal and other can have high refractive errors. The abnormal eye can be a lazy eye also, if at all not identified and treated in the earlier ages. Normally  it is not noticed since we tend to keep both the eyes open always, unless we have the habit of winking ???!! The abnormal eye needs to be treated with glasses or contact lenses to have a comfortable binocular vision if possible. author: Dr. Ramamurthy M G  Medical Doctor Posts: 90 Joined: Sun Dec 28, 2008 9:47 pm Gender: Male
title: Re: Cause of sudden droopy eyelid 8 month old?
content: Hi, Sorry for a very delayed reply. Hopefully your child is better now. The droopy eye lids may be related to a an insect bite, mild trauma, or a mild infection, where it regresses on its own with treatment. If it is neurological, because of some head injury, as suspected, it needs to be investigated and can be treated. Regarding amblyopia, unless there is a  gross disturbance to the vision, because of severe drooping, there is no issue. Amblyopia cannot set in so soon. We need to assess the child around 3-4 yrears, subjectively and if at all any doubts, it  needs be treated. Untill the retinal neurological development is complete, say upto 12 years, there are good chances to treat amblyopia. Normally amblyopia does not cause the drooping, where as the severe drooping, untreated over a period of time ,might cause an amblyopia. As of now, if it is not regressing contact your family eye doctor, and take his advice. Regards, Dr.Ramamurthy M G

title: Mysterious bluriness, afterimages, etc in young person
content: Here's a chronology of what's been going on.  I’ve included everything in case something is relevant that I wasn’t away of.    Family history: *Aunt on father's side with diabetes and schizophrenia *Uncle on mother's side died at age 57 of heart attack *Brother has slight heart arrhythmia that does not affect his activity  Age 4: *Surgery due to weak muscle in left eye  Most of life: *Frequent double vision - seeing two of the same thing due to the offset between the eyes *Occasional fainting, usually from needles (getting shots or getting blood drawn); this happened a few times also from getting hit in the head.  MRI and EEG at age 10 do not indicate any issues.  1994 (Age 13): *Hands and feet become extremely swollen.  Doctor gives pills that I have to take for a week or else I get a lot of spots all over me.  Allergy skin-test a few weeks later comes up totally negative.  Cause for outbreak never determined.  1999 *Blood in urine after working out; ultrasound indicates no issues.  Summer 2001L *Moved to Europe for a year.  Began getting symptoms such as: (1) strong awareness of heartbeat, (2) shortness of breath (3) difficulty sleeping.  Doctor says this is stress.  After a month calms down to a manageable level.  EKG (while resting) is normal.  10/2001: *Was unknowingly hashish by friends; began shaking  like crazy and kept forgetting where I was - and thought something was seriously wrong with me.  I was mostly better after a few hours.  4/2002: *Wake up with very sore and tense neck, shoulders, and lower back.  Orthopedist  indicates that vertebrae in neck are straight when they should be arranged in a curve Physical therapy and acupuncture reduce problem but it is never fully solved.  8/2002 – 6/2006 (In college): *Become sexually active, but never engage in activities of significant risk * After jogging, often feel mild chest pains that go away soon *In architecture school, am occasionally exposed to (1) solvents (2) fumes from laser-cutting acrylic, wood, and cardboard and (3) sawdust *Frequently get much too little sleep due to school  8/2007 (Age 24): *Enter graduate school for architecture.   *Get nervous because hairline is receding significantly even though no one in my family has hair loss; doctor says this is genetic.  I do not treat it. *Begin again to be occasionally exposed to (1) solvents for melting acrylic (2) fumes from laser-cutting acrylic, wood, and cardboard (3) sawdust (4) glues and (5) spraypaint *Begin again to frequently get much too little sleep due to school demands *Occasionally watch laser-cutter, which means I am looking at intense laser light, although it is not pointing at my eyes.  3/2008: *Travel to Asia for the first time  4/2008: *Sexual activity with somebody new; do not engage in any particularly risky activity. *For one week, get a few quarter-sized white bumps on hips each day.  Spots are in different location each day.  5/2008 *Notice shadowing double-vision on text on computer screen; this is different than my typical double vision because it is present in each eye individually (when I close one eye, there is still double vision).  This is present in each eye.  Scares me, but is gone in the morning.  6/2008: *Wake up and notice that one eye is very blurry.  Does not go away after an hour so I go see doctor.  They do exams on me but can't find anything wrong other than my pupils are abnormally large.  Bluriness eventually diminishes. *Begin to notice what I call "spotiness" in my vision: general inability to see clearly - it's a little blurry but more than that, colors are not solid colors but rather seem to be constantly overlaid with see-through, moving spots/areas that are dark on light colored materials and light on dark-colored materials.  I am not sure exactly how to describe this ; This is my biggest symptom that persists. *First appointment with optometrist.  Exam does not reveal any issues.  Says right eye is dominant.  Says I have mild astigmatism in both eyes, but that this wouldn't cause intermittent double-vision in each eye individually.  Optometrist gives me optional prescription for glasses that I never get because prescription is so mild.  Overall, says she sees nothing wrong with my eyes.  7-8/2008 * Problems continue as described earlier *Blurry vision persists; monocular double vision (especially for text) comes back occasionally; often just feel really out of it: kind of lightheaded, nervous, mild difficulty speaking.  Out-of-it feeling tends to come on suddenly. *Very obvious after-images on from computer screen in dark room *A few weeks later, feel even more out of it.  Frequently get winded from brisk walking and don't seem to become un-winded as normal.  Eventually feel somewhat better. *One night, get bad diarrhea; people say I look pale and out of it. *For a week, frequently get swollen ankles and hands and itchy spots on legs. *Ga new sexual partner and do not engage in any particularly risky behavior.  9/2008: *Blurriness in vision, "spottiness" continues.  Out-of-it feeling frequently returns. *Feel sensitive to light; eyes feel under pressure. *Go see ophthalmologist; says there is nothing wrong with my eyes and passes my on to my GP *Get MRI of brain; brain scan is normal although it shows a mild sinus problem.  ThisI rules out tumors and MS? *Blookwork done; bloodcounts normal.  Thyroid normal.  Cholesterol normal.  Everything is normal.  10/2008: *Notice consistent see-through dark-spot in far right of left eye's field of vision. *Go to allergist; diagnoses skin bumps as hives but can't find a source for them.  Allergist has urine and stool samples done, which are normal. *Resting EKG done, which is also normal. *Neurologist exam reveals nothing abnormal.  Neurologist thinks all of my problems are due to allergies and adrenaline (even though I have never had any allergies, have no family history of such, and don't have traditional allergy symptoms) and does not order an EEG.  The allergist is skeptical of the neurologist's diagnosis.  November 2008: *Am sick for a week.  Doesn't seem like a traditional flu or a cold.  No digestive problems.  Not much of a cough or fever.  Every  night I  had very significant shivering also sweat through my clothes and sheets. Had a very dry mouth for one day.  January 2009: *Begin new semester.  Spotty vision (which I described before as constant overlaying of mild, moving discoloration, kind-of like afterimages) and mild bluriness continues as before and seems to gets worse; I often feel slightly out-of-it and my vision makes it very annoying to read a book or work at a computer, although I can still do it.  I have been feeling a little lightheaded frequently.  I've been exercising less and frequently feel abnormally winded when I do exercise.  I sleep for long enough at night although I've been waking up frequently.  I've been feeling fatigued and rather lethargic most days.  I've been getting occasional mild chest pains and headaches.  Any ideas what could be going on?  Why do I have such significant vision symptoms but the opthamologist, neurologist, allergist, etc can't find anything wrong with me?  Is the neurologist's diagnosis of it simply being allergies and adreneline feasible?  I am getting very nervous - the vision is affecting how I am able to live to my life and is also impacting my optimism for the future because I am afraid it will get worse.  Because of these symptoms I continue to be afraid of brain problems, heart problems, and diseases.  Did I pick up some disease from vistting China or from a sexual partner?  Do I have an impending neurological disorder?  Did I look too long at the laser light from the laser-cutter (even though it was not pointing at my eyes)?  Did I inhale too many solvents (even though it hasn't been all that many)?  Thanks! -NB

title: Re: Mysterious bluriness, afterimages, etc in young person
content: hi,first and the foremost you look to be really worried a lot, I guess. Be relaxed, whatever is there, will be there and whatever is not will not be there. We need to take proper consultation and relevant treatment from proper specialists, which you have been already doing. You can always take a second opinion from the other neurologist if it is really required and if it is possible, with all your old reports. I do feel most of your problems are related to vascular system where blood supply comes into the picture, and which are mediated because of disturbance in the blood supply to various organ systems including eye. So, you can contact a cardiologist/ physician, who can help you out in terms of the investigations, related to vascular supply- like doppler studies? carotid doppler study? related to eye/ brain. It rules out TIA -Transient ischaemic attack, loss of vision, even though age is not favourable. Symptoms might be related to Migaine/Ocular migraine where one might have disturbance in the vision and visual field, during attacks.If it is a migraine the insighting cause/ trigger/s need to be avoided to get the relief/ attacks along with the treatment. Coming to the eye it might be the focussing problems, related to mild muscle weakness/ refractive error, continous near work, continous glare and bright light related issues, eye fatigue etc. Proper glasses with repeated relaxation has to be planned. I did not see any readings related to eye pressures-IOPS, which is also very important in your case along with the study of  angles of the eye. Relavant treatment needs to be started if found necessary. Raised IOPS along with narrow angles, can be one of the reason for your presenting symptoms.Hope the information helps you. With Regards, Dr.Ramamurthy M G

posted_time: Post  by jeansmithy » Sun Jan 18, 2009 6:20 pm

author: Dr. Ramamurthy M G  Medical Doctor Posts: 90 Joined: Sun Dec 28, 2008 9:47 pm Gender: Male
title: Re: retina question on laser treatment - how many spots?
content: Hello/ Hi, for proliferative diabetic retinopathy, requiring laser photo coagulation, a procedure called pan retinal photocoagulation , can be done where in the entire retina is burnt with laser spots, in one or two sittings, depending on the need. The central area called macula, which is the central sensitive spot for a clear vision, which is normally an avascular zone is left untouched. The patient might have loss of perperal vision with visual field loss and disturbed night vision.Preferably the laser burn is put only in the proliferative areas, either focal, or grid where we see new blood vessels and edema if the entire retina is not involved. Hope I have given enough information. With regards, Dr.Ramamurthy M G

author: Dr. Ramamurthy M G  Medical Doctor Posts: 90 Joined: Sun Dec 28, 2008 9:47 pm Gender: Male
title: Re: retina question on laser treatment - how many spots?
content: Hello, in either of the cases, new vessel or normal vessel, the blood vessels are not treated directly with the laser shots, the sorrounding retinal area of the new vessels are treated, to indirectly regress the new vessels. In the pan retinal phto- coagulation the main trunks and branches are avoided while treating the retina and may be the tiny capillaries might get burnt in the process with the direct shots. The new vessels if they don't get regressed, even after treatment, might be occassionlly treated with the direct shots, at the end to avoid unnecessary bleeding. Before that  anti vascular growth factrors , steroid injections into the eye directly, can be given to address the issue. with regards, Dr.Ramamurthy M G

The doctor said without another surgery, he will lose his eye. They are planning to do another surgery in a few days, to reattach the retina again (it has dettached for a second time). They are going to insert some fluid to hold the retina in place, and put a buckel around the eye. The surgeon has said that this is the last hope for saving his eye. There is a 10% chance of saving his eye with this surgery. Is there really nothing else that could be done at this point and if not why? Iv'e tried to do research, but I don't know where to start. They say his eye is severly damaged. If it helps, the procedures he's had done are: surgery lensectomy/vitrectomy/removal of copper bb, and what I have mentioned above. They said we have a two week time frame to do something, so I really would like some feedback if possible, and thank you in advance. He has no problems medically, is active and healthy. author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: lose part of vision
content: Hi there -  This is very likely one of two things, and it should be checked by an opthamologist ASAP. It may be optical migraine, which is harmless in itself, or it may be a partially detached retina, which can be more of a problem. Optical migraine is usually something one just has to learn to deal with, and at least doesn't have the headaches that usually follow these auras. A detached retina needs attention promptly, so that needs to be ruled out.  There are other possible causes that are far less likely, but if neither of the above turn out to be the problem, then as unlikely as it seems, you'll need to have transient ischemic attack (TIA or "mini-stroke") ruled out. It really doesn't sound like that's what's happening, but it would show up further down the list if neither of the first two things proves to be the case. I wouldn't be overly concerned about that, but it has to be considered if there is no other apparent  cause. This can also be a more benign phenomenon (since you mentioned this started when you'd have your head tilted) in that some people can actually kink one of the carotid arteries by head positioning, sometimes because of a partial blockage,sometimes due to a simple anatomical anomaly.  I hope this is helpful. Please follow up with us as needed.

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: Re: Left eye watering, stinging, red, hot, photosensitive
content: Hello -  Conjunctivitis, an inflamation of the cornea, can be bacterial, allergic, or even viral. Since in your case it goes away when the contacts are removed and the affected eye is medicated, the irritation subsides, and when a new contact  is placed in the eye the inflammation returns. This suggests this is not a bacterial infection, since it would almost certainly spread to the other eye, and definitely that the contacts are not contaminated, or both eyes would be affected. Therefore while it could be an allergic reaction, again the other eye would be affected also. What is most likely, therefore, I would think, is that you have a (relatively) deep corneal scratch which has become infected. These tend to seal  over, so when infection occurs as a result, it doesn't always spread to the other eye.  All your symptoms suggest this, rather than simple  conjuntivitis (or pinkeye), which usually responds readily to treatment and would be expected to spread to both eyes.    The sensitivity to light is what makes me believe you have a scratched cornea with a covered infection, although it also could be a viral lesion of the affected cornea. These are generally easy to spot, however, so it's less likely.  I think it may be time to see an opthamologist about this, so that the cause can be pinpointed and treated properly, both for the sake of relieving the instense discomfort and to prevent actual damage to the eye.  I hope this is helpful to you. Please follow up  with  us on  this.

title: Eye Infection gets worse with Antiobiotics..
content: Last friday, September 19th I woke up with some irritation in my right eye. It was a little swollen and itchy and burning. I flushed it with eye wash solution but as the day progressed so did the pain, scratchiness and burning to an intolerable state. I went to urgent care and he looked an saw no corneal abrasions of any sort, he gave me prescription antibiotic eye drops. Consequently, I have been on levaquin for three days prior (750 mg OD) for bronchitis. Let me preface this with I do not wear contact lenses and in my 46  years of life have never had an eye infection. By the next day the eye is even worse, I call the eye doctor and go in an see him, he gives me Tobradex which is an antibiotic drop with steriodal medication to help reduce swelling and tells me it should start feeling better by the evening. Two days go by and its Monday and the eye continues to worsen instead of improve, more redness and swelling not only of the eye but all around it and it's halfway closed now. I call the opthalmologist back, go in and see him and he tells me to wait three more days and if it's not better he's putting me on IV antibiotics. Well, that was yesterday, I have been up all night in severe pain not only in my eye but the whole side of my face and the inflammation is worse. I also have light sensitivity and blurred vision. My question is, should I see another doctor, why would this doc make me wait another three days if my condition hasn't responded in the time it should given this particular medication...what is he missing??

title: is amblyopia hereditary?
content: Is amblyopia hereditary? I was born with it, and although no one else in my family has it, I'm still afraid to have kids. Could I pass this down to my children?
posted_time: Post  by aarogers » Sat Aug 30, 2008 11:00 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: is amblyopia hereditary?
content: Hello, Yes, amblyopia can be hereditary but it is not always associated with family involvement.  There is such a myriad of disorders that can be passed on genetically.  If we avoided them all, nobody would have children.  Whether or not you feel you want children and can raise them well is a personal decision but I certainly would not avoid the joys that can come when you are ready to have a family based on this minor impairment possibility.  There are life-threatening conditions that might make me feel that way but not something as easily treated as this one.  Just follow up with good pediatric care so early intervention can be utilized if needed.  Best wishes.

content: Hello -  This sounds odd but may be normal. I'd need some more information, however, to be able to say whether it sounds like a normal phenomenon or something really odd and out of my range. What I'd like to know is: Does this stripe run horizontally across the eyeball or does it encircle the pupil? The former is something I have never heard of or seen. author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: i hardly can open my eyes.
content: Hello, I assume it is an eye doctor you are seeing.  This can be a symptom of an underlying disorder, problem with pupil contraction, possibly even macular degeneration (among other possibilities).  I assume you aren't taking medications that have this side effect, but you did not specify one way or the other.    Light sensitivity can be related to migraines.  Sometimes it is not related to any disorder (it's just the way you are) and cannot be treated or cured.  In these cases it is important to learn to adapt to the condition.  You should get good, larger than normal, wrap-around sunglasses with UV filters (sometimes called solar lenses) and wear a hat with a brim to reduce glare.      You may also benefit from consulting someone who works with people who have sight impairment - people who advocate and assist the visually impaired, low-vision specialists, etc.  These folks can help you learn to adapt.  Good luck.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: eye pulse
content: Hi Johnnnie2000,  The pulsing you are feeling may be muscle twitching in the eye muscles.  These can occur similar to twitches of muscles in other parts of the body.  There are many causes of these types of muscle twitches.  One of the more common ones is an electrolyte deficiency such as not having enough potassium or calcium in the diet.  You may want to see a doctor about this for further evaluation.  Your electrolyte levels can be tested although this actually may not necessarily correlate well.  Taking a daily multivitamin may help if it is an electrolyte issue.  There are several other causes as well that your doctor can help evaluate for.  Best wishes.

My eyes turned red and they were burning.So i went to an urgent care and they told me to wash out my eyes with saline solution.I did that and the burning went away. Now i am seeing increased floaters and spots and some bluriness in my eyes. Is this from the inflammation and should i go see an opthamologist.Is it too late?
posted_time: Post  by JohnnyCash433 » Sat Dec 29, 2007 10:40 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Seeing Spots and Floaters
content: Inflammation in the eye can cause these symptoms and chances are this is transient.  Most spots and floaters are harmless and fade over time. However, the sudden appearance of a significant number of floaters, especially if they are accompanied by flashes of light or other vision disturbances, could indicate a retinal detachment or other serious problem in the eye. If you suddenly see new floaters, visit your eye doctor immediately.  Since you did go to an instant care facility, I suspect this is just your response to the irritation and will decrease in time.  It never hurts to have an eye exam however, just to be sure.  Everyone should have their eyes examined periodically, even if they do not need vision correction.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Fri Jan 04, 2008 9:01 am

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: I have something in my eye - any over the counter medicine?
content: Hello, I know of nothing that can remove foreign objects from your eye.  If it is still bothering you it could be that it is scratched and will heal on its own but in the meantime it may feel like something is in there.  Try to rest your eye as much as possible.  If it still feels like a foreign body but you can't see it, the only answer would be the eye washing - regular water will do, but wash it for several minutes.  Aside from this you would have to see a doctor.  While insurance makes it much easier to get medical care, consider that not paying premiums also frees up some money to pay for a doctor visit.  So, even though it seems steep, the total of several months of insurance premiums can actually top that cost.  The savings you have realized may compensate.  I would recommend that an uninsured person try to put aside what might be spent otherwise to buy insurance into an earmarked account for medical needs.  I know it wouldn't cover something big like hospitalization and it's harder because it isn't done automatically through payroll, but it could help in these cases.    Best wishes and Happy New Year.

I rub to try and stop it but it just continues. I've put eye drops in it aswell.  I started noticing that my right eye is starting to do the same. What the heck is it and What can I do to stop it?

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Often eye twitching is in response to eye irritation. This may result from exposure to overly bright lights, eye strain, prolonged staring, or being overly tired (fatigue).     It becomes worse when you think about it so the best thing to do is to try and relax along with getting plenty of sleep - even short naps periodically throughout the day.  Cognitive behavior therapies can help you learn to reduce stress which can also trigger this condition.  There is no known cure for this, though trials are being done now involving botox.    Good luck

author: mikemac  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Sun Sep 16, 2007 6:18 pm
title: Strabismus correction
content: Hello,  When i was a baby both my eyes turned in. At about 18months old i had an operation on the right eye to straighten the eye. Then at 3 years old i had an operation on my left to straighten.   In the following years i was prescribed glasses and also used eye patches and eye drops. Then at 8 years old i was discharged by my doctor and told that there was no need to wear the glasses anymore or for any other treatment (although on occasion i still would wear my glasses when i had a headache, as wearing the glasses would make the headache go away). However i was told that in later life i may want a operation for cosmetic reasons.   In my later teens i noticed that my left eye would turn out whenever i was over tired, drunk, etc. Then when i was about 22 years old that left had turned out almost permanently. At 24 years old i had a operation on the left eye only, which was to straighten the eye. After the operation everyone told that the left looked a lot straighter, although i thought that it still turned out (but it was quite hard to judge as the eye had not fully healed/opened). Now 5 months after the operation the i have noticed that the left eye has turned out permanently.  So my questions are would another operation on the left eye be worthwhile? (as i have been informed it can quite often take two operations to get the eyes in alignmnet)  Would useing eye patches or eye drops be effective? (or am i to old for these treatments to work).  If another operation would prove effective and is the best option, would having the operation done privately be a good idea?   I have been told that going private for eye operations quite often produces better results (i mean no offence to the NHS). Mainly because there hospitals are specialised eye clinics, and there equipment for measuring how much the eye has turned out is state of the art and so more accurate.  Sorry if i have given to much information, and feel free to ask any questions if you need any more information.  I hope you can help. Cheers, mike.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hi Mike,  I'm not an ophthalmologist so please keep this in mind as you hear my thoughts.  Generally, the patching/eye drops only works when patients are younger.  Once the eye pathways have fully matured the patching is unlikely to be effective.  If your vision is now good you may not need further surgery.  If you are having any double vision or eye problems, the corrective surgery may help some.    If your vision is OK and you are not satisfied with the  cosmetic results of the eye alignment further surgery may help also.  I would recommend you discuss the benefits and risks with an ophthalmologist to be able to make an informed decision.  Unfortunately, I cannot comment about the differences between private and NHS surgeries.  I do not have any knowledge of the specifics of this.  Best wishes.

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: A sty involves glands and eyelash hair follicles that are closer to the skin surface of the eyelid than the chalazion, which involves a sweat gland within the eyelid. These are not usually not serious but can be painful and annoying.  Apply warm packs frequently to help healing.  Any time you get a regular recurrence it is smart to see your ophthalmologist for evaluation to be sure there is not something more serious going on.  If eyelid redness or swelling does not improve with warm towel compresses in 3-4 days.  You should contact your ophthalmologist immediately if you have frequent bouts of eyelid swelling or if you experience any of the following: Fever, headache, visual changes (eg, blurred vision, decreased ability to see), eye pain or drainage, extensive swelling, if both the upper eyelid and the lower eyelid of one eye are swollen

content: I was recently diagnosed with ocular herpes. My eye had been infected for almost two weeks when the diagnosis of herpes simplex was made by an ophthalmologist. My ophthalmologist has examined my eyes on a fairly regular basis and found no signs of acute disease in my eye but he has not offered any explanation for the ongoing symptoms expect to suggest that I ask my primary care physician about the sinus problems. posted_time: Post  by Poda » Tue Jan 30, 2007 9:42 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: It is normal for people to get the occasional floater.  However, persistent floaters are an indication that something is going on until proven otherwise.  There are a few possible causes.  Retina problems can cause floaters to appear.  They may also be an early warning of an impending migraine headache.  Rarely, they may be seen with migraine headaches that do not actually have a headache.  They may also be seen in association with high blood pressure.  If your ophthalmologist is confident that your eyes are not the cause  and the floaters persist you should see your regular doctor for a full evaluation.  At that point, referral to a neurologist may be needed.  Best wishes.

content: Dear dooper,  i think you are right. If your friend is getting worse even though he is taking his eye drops on regular basis, i think he needs to ask his doctor to change his medications, or seek a second opinion. Loss of vision from glaucoma (increased intracranial pressure) in most cases, should be preventable.  i am not an ophthalmologist but i think that there are types of glaucoma that are treated with surgery.  i think you should urge your friend to talk to his doctor about other options or seek a second opinion. author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  I am sorry to hear what your brother has just gone through. I am not an ophthalmologist but I can tell you that there are many causes for sudden unilateral loss of vision.   These include ocular ischemia resulting from atherosclerosis, emboli from various sources, arteritis, tumors and other conditions of the brain and orbit. It may also result as a complication of classic migraine.  In addition there are some reports of sudden monocular visual loss due to nonarteric anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) with the use of drugs such as quinidine, sildenafil (Viagra), vardenafil (Levitra), and tadalafil (Cialis).  I would think a good way to start searching for a cause would be an ophthalmoscopy and maybe an MRI of the brain and orbit or a carotid angiography.  Please note that he does appear to have a poor lipid profile making carotid atherosclerosis a possibility.  Best regards,

content: cgreenwell wrote:My son was born 1lb 11oz back in 1995.   Development of vision is a gradual process. First few years of life are too crucial.  If the light rays doesn't reach the retina for some reason or the other, the vision is hampered permanently. Either partially or fully. You haven't mentioned whether he had vision loss since birth or it diminished gradually. As a pre-mature baby he suffered many surgeries and made it. However, he has optic nerve damage and He was diagnosed yesterday that he was legally blind. He does have scarring on both eyes.     Scarring most likely suggests involvement of cornea. Again, if it is since birth, it hampers vision development as no light reach retina.  Also, optic nerve seems to be involved due to whatever reasons. Optic nerve carries visual signals from eye to brain.   * Can he have an optic nerve transplant?    No.  * Will a corneal transplant help him?    No. Even if Cornea is transplanted, the rays will ultimately reach retina. And from retina it will need an optic nerve to carry the visual impluse from the eye to the brain.  Also I am not very sure about the status of the retina. * How difficult or easy is it to get donors for this?    There are many who donate their eyes after the death. Getting a donor shouldn't be an issue as such. But point is, is it worth it? * Is there hope that someday technology will give him sight again?    Theorotically - Maybe.  Practically - No.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: The ciliary body is the structure in the eye that secretes the transparent liquid within the eye (aqueous humor). It also contains the ciliary muscle, which changes the shape of the lens when your eyes focus.   Glaucoma is increased pressure in the eyeball due to obstruction of the outflow of aqueous humor; damages the optic disc and impairs vision (sometimes progressing to blindness).  Several treatment options are available that are designed to decrease the ciliary body's production of aqueous humor. These include medical as well as surgical and laser techniques. But before we get into any of that she should be examined and it should be established first whether she indeed has glaucoma or not. If its just the bleeding (hyphema). Blood usually reabsorbs, but the doctor must make sure the process is resolving itself. If intraocular pressure increases or if bleeding reoccurs, she may be hospitalized.

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: Your father's arterial blood pressure and his intraocular pressure readings are required for a suitable response to your question.  His blood pressure medication will require an adjustment in current dosage or a change of drug if the blood pressure is not adequately controlled.   He must see an ophthalmologist for an evaluation of his eyes and a physician for blood pressure monitoring. Hypertension may cause complications in various organs of the body, including the eyes, and untreated glaucoma may cause progressive loss of vision. author: badodge  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Sep 22, 2004 10:29 pm Location: Florida
title: blindness
content: My 36-year-old daughter had a heart attack and lacked oxygen to the brain for several minutes. She can walk, talk, and perform many daily functions with little or no help. Her long term and short term memory is good. She has some cognitive lapses.  Her major concern is her vision. At times she can recognize colors, faces and objects around her. Then she says everything just goes away, like someone has closed her eyes.   She can look at a wall and see one or two items (e.g. a curtain) but not everything on the wall (e.g. a picture). She sometimes can see one person in a room, but not another standing next to the original person.   She does not always realize she can see and mentions something like “it is raining” when looking out a window. When asked how she knows’ she is somewhat surprised and realizes and says, ” Because I saw the rain”. And then the vision is gone. Many times she avoids items put in front of her, while other times she does not see them.  It does not appear there is one area or the eye that allows her to “see”, because when she “experiences vision” it can be in front of her or to her left or right side.   She has had an MRI, which showed little damage, and no sign of what would be responsible for cortical blindness. She has also been seen by an optometrist and has no damage to the retina or optical nerve.   She remains in the hospital, but the doctors say they cannot explain her blindness and sometimes there are no answers to why the brain responds as it does.   Does anyone have a better explanation or suggestions for tests I should request? Barb

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male

content: Hello badodge, It seems that your daughter could be suffering from something known as agnosia. This is the inability to recognize objects, colours or people seen. This could be a result of her cerebral ischemia. There are many types of agnosia and I would advise you to seek the attention of a neurologist that is experienced in this topic.

author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: maiden, what you are experiencing is called an "aura".  It is very common symptom with migraines, more commonly happens just preceding one.  The neck pain is also an extension of migraines sometimes.   When you get an aura, you should take whatever medication works for you at that point in time.  Something with caffiene is usually the best over the counter treatment, like Excedrin or a generic equivalent, provided you don't have a history of ulcers.  It has aspirin, Tylenol and a small amount of caffiene, about the same amount as in a cup of coffee.  It doesn't give very many people the jitters.

author: Dr. Heba Ismail  Medical Doctor Posts: 328 Joined: Tue Sep 21, 2004 4:08 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello jillyb118, I'm afraid I'm not an ophthalmologist, but would like to help nonetheless! Here are a few things you should know that you may find helpful. First of all, you have to know that nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) should be absolutely avoided in your sons case. A patient with a hyphema who has a normal IOP is usually treated with corticosteroids and cycloplegics, but that depends on what your doctor recommends. IOP reduction is usually necessary if it is higher than 30 mm Hg. Patients with early IOP elevation following blunt trauma should be reexamined every 4-6 weeks during the first year to monitor the condition. Some early cases are self-limited, but patients should continue to be observed after the condition has appeared to resolve. Other early cases represent a severe form of the disease that may be refractory to standard medical treatment; such cases warrant more frequent follow up. Blunt eye trauma can interfere with the function of the nerve supply to the iris (parasympathetic nerves) resulting in dilation of the pupil. As for retinal involvement and vision, ultimate outcome depends upon time, degree of damage and whether the macula (central part of the retina) is involved or not.

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: pinkeye
content: Hello,  Did they give you any medication for your eye? You should ask your Physician to swab your eye to recheck that the treatment is appropriate for the infection if you feel it isn’t working.  Conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctiva which is a thin, clear membrane covering the white of the eyeball and the inside of the eyelid. There are different causes of conjunctivitis and treatment will differ depending upon the cause.   Viral conjunctivitis usually affects only one eye and causes excessive eye watering and a light discharge.  Bacterial conjunctivitis affects both eyes and causes a heavy discharge, sometimes greenish.  Allergic conjunctivitis affects both eyes and causes itching and redness in the eyes and sometimes the nose, as well as excessive tearing.  Giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC) usually affects both eyes and causes contact lens intolerance, itching, a heavy discharge, tearing and red bumps on the underside of the eyelids.   To pinpoint the cause and then choose an appropriate treatment, your doctor will ask some questions, examine your eyes, and possibly collect a sample on a swab to send out for analysis. Always wash your hands before touching your eyes, try to keep touching at a minimum and don’t use eye drops unless directed to by your Physician, even to get the red out – they make the irritation worse.

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: eye nystagmus
content: This note was posted in January 2003 but I am responding to it because there are probably others with this problem that I think should read this.   There are medical conditions that can cause nystagmus, if you have eye problems go to your family physician or optometrist and get it checked out. If you haven't had a physical with blood work done in a while, I would recommend it. Some medical conditions can sneak up on you with strange symptoms you aren't expecting, don't overlook your bodies signs for help.
